data.text:
Well, I was in the mood for a cyberpunk novel. And, although Iâ€™d originally planned to re-read William Gibsonâ€™s â€œNeuromancerâ€, I happened to spot my copies of Gibsonâ€™s â€œBridge Trilogyâ€ that Iâ€™d been meaning to read for about a decade or so.

So, wanting to try something slightly different, I thought that Iâ€™d take a look at the first novel in the trilogy, â€œVirtual Lightâ€ (1993), today ğŸ™‚

Needless to say, this review may contain some SPOILERS.

Set in in the high-tech near-future year of 2005, the novel begins with a mysterious description of a man watching several video feeds from a hotel room in Mexico City.

Meanwhile, in Los Angeles, ex-cop and private security officer Berry Rydell is driving around with his allergy-ridden partner Sublett. Their night is filled with a series of bizarre events that lead to Rydell crashing the van into a house. Although Rydell isnâ€™t fired over the mistake, he ends up resigning from the security company when faced with the prospect of being relegated to uneventful guard duty.

In San Francisco, a bicycle courier called Chevette is delivering a package to a posh hotel. After dropping off the package, she is about to go back to her bike when she meets a drunken woman in a lift who invites her to a party in one of the hotel rooms. During the party, a sleazy guy starts hassling Chevette and, out of spite, she steals a pair of expensive-looking sunglasses from his jacket before leaving the party.

Back in Los Angeles, Rydellâ€™s flatmate Hernandez eventually gets him a job as a freelance driver for a skip tracer in San Francisco called Warbaby. When Rydell arrives, Warbaby tells him that a man has been murdered and a very important pair of sunglasses have been stolenâ€¦

One of the first things that I will say about this novel is that, although itâ€™ll take you a while to get used to Gibsonâ€™s trademark writing style, this story is a really compelling cyberpunk/post-cyberpunk thriller. In addition to making me feel nostalgic about the first time I read Gibsonâ€™s â€œNeuromancerâ€, it also reminded me a bit of Neal Stephensonâ€™s â€œSnow Crashâ€ and M. John Harrisonâ€™s â€œNova Swingâ€ too. Which is never a bad thing ğŸ™‚

In terms of the novelâ€™s sci-fi elements, this novel mostly takes the post-cyberpunk approach of focusing on ordinary peopleâ€™s lives in a futuristic tech-filled dystopia. Yes, there are a few hints of the virtual reality hacking of â€œNeuromancerâ€ here and loads of subtly futuristic and/or â€œedgyâ€ background details, but this is more of a story about people trying to make a living in a moderately dystopian future. In essence, this is a drama set in a somewhat cyberpunk world rather than a traditional cyberpunk story.

But, what a world it is ğŸ™‚ Although this novel contains quite a few â€œrealisticâ€ urban settings, they are filled with enough futuristic tech and/or bizarre backstory to make them absolutely fascinating. Even so, the best location in the novel is the Golden Gate bridge, which has been turned into this wonderfully atmospheric rusting, neon-lit, rainy, ramshackle anarchist encampment. And, yes, like in the modern computer game â€œShadowrun: Dragonfallâ€œ, this novel actually contains a fairly nuanced depiction of what an anarchist society would look like.

As for the novelâ€™s thriller elements, although this story is a bit of a slow burn at times, it gets more suspenseful and action-packed as it progresses. Even so, the novel uses a few classic thriller techniques like mini-cliffhangers and alternating plot threads throughout the novel. Itâ€™s also the kind of story which starts out fairly randomly and then gradually becomes more and more focused too.

Thematically, this novel is fairly interesting too. In addition to being a novel about authority, itâ€™s also a story about things like gentrification, the unreliability of history, religion, the media, income inequality etcâ€¦ too. Cyberpunk fiction is, after all, one of the most thematically complex genres of science fiction out there. Even so, most of this stuff feels slightly more like a background detail than you might expect.

In terms of the characters, this novel is fairly good. Although all of the characters in this novel are slightly stylised, they really feel like part of the storyâ€™s world. Many of them also get a reasonable amount of backstory and characterisation too. Not to mention that, if youâ€™re a fan of Neal Stephensonâ€™s â€œSnow Crashâ€, then the fact that one of the main characters in â€œVirtual Lightâ€ (Chevette) is also a punk-like courier is pretty cool too.

In terms of the writing, this novel is really good when you get used to Gibsonâ€™s writing style. The novelâ€™s third-person narration has a really distinctive voice that is both very â€œmatter of factâ€/hardboiled and very detailed at the time. Itâ€™s fast-paced and slow-paced at the same time. It has some really interesting experimental flourishes (eg: mixing past and present events and tenses etc..) and itâ€™s also kind of a more subtle and realistic version of the intentionally confusing â€œbombard the reader with futuristic detailsâ€ technique that Gibson uses to great effect in â€œNeuromancerâ€.

If youâ€™ve read and enjoyed slightly more obscure genres of fiction (eg: cyberpunk fiction, hardboiled detective fiction, beat literature, gonzo journalism etc..) in the past, then youâ€™ll â€œgetâ€ the writing style of this novel and really enjoy it ğŸ™‚ But, if youâ€™ve only read more â€œtraditionalâ€ fiction, then you might find the writing style in this novel mildly confusing.

In terms of length and pacing, this novel is really interesting. At 294 pages in length, this novel feels both shorter and longer than this. In short, whilst it only has a fraction of the epic scale of â€“ say â€“ Neal Stephensonâ€™s â€œSnow Crashâ€ or â€œThe Diamond Ageâ€, the novel still somehow feels longer than a typical 200-300 page novel.

A lot of this probably has to do with the pacing. In short, this is the most fast-paced slow-paced novel youâ€™ll ever read. Whilst each sentence flows breathlessly into the next, there is so much detail to keep track of that each page will take longer to read than you expect. But, on the whole, the novelâ€™s pacing is fairly good â€“ with the story gradually becoming more focused and suspenseful as it progresses.

As for how this twenty-six year old novel has aged, it has aged interestingly. Leaving aside a few â€œedgyâ€ and/or â€œpolitically incorrectâ€ moments, itâ€™s intriguing to see what this novel predicted correctly (eg: augmented reality glasses, flat-screen TVs, the disturbing trend of â€œSwattingâ€œ, an Anonymous-like group of hackers etcâ€¦) and what it got wrong (eg: people still using fax machines, various medical advances, a lot of the novelâ€™s history etc..). Still, if you ignore the fact that this novel is supposed to be set in 2005, then itâ€™s a really interesting and atmospheric cyberpunk story that is still enjoyable to read.

All in all, whilst this novel probably isnâ€™t for everyone, it is a really interesting and atmospheric cyberpunk thriller. Although it isnâ€™t quite as good as â€œNeuromancerâ€ and it lacks some of the depth and scale that you might expect, itâ€™s still really cool to read a 20th century William Gibson novel ğŸ™‚ Likewise, if youâ€™re a fan of Neal Stephensonâ€™s â€œSnow Crashâ€, itâ€™s really interesting to see what Gibson can do with some of the themes/ideas from that novel.

If I had to give it a rating out of five, it would get at least a four.
